sen.j: 西田 幾多郎（にしだ きたろう、1870年5月19日（明治3年4月19日 (旧暦)） - 1945年（昭和20年）6月7日）は日本を代表する哲学者であり京都大学教授、名誉教授。
sen.e: Kitaro NISHIDA (May 19, 1870-June 7, 1945) was a philosopher, professor and honorary professor of Kyoto University who represented Japan.
Kitaro NISHIDA (May 19, 1870 - June 7, 1945) was a representative Japanese philosopher, professor and honorary professor of Kyoto University.
Kitaro NISHIDA (May 19, 1870 - June 7, 1945) was a representative Japanese philosopher, professor and honorary professor of Kyoto University.

sen.j: 京都学派の創始者。
sen.e: Founder of Kyoto shool
He was the founder of the Kyoto School
He was the founder of the Kyoto School

sen.j: 同郷の鈴木大拙（本名：貞太郎）、山本良吉、藤岡作太郎とは石川県専門学校（第四高等中学校の前身、のちの第四高等学校 (旧制)）以来の友人であり、西田、鈴木、藤岡の三人は加賀の三太郎と称された。
sen.e: Daisetsu SUZUKI (real name: Sadataro), Ryokichi YAMAMOTO, Sakutaro FUJIOKA who were born in the same prefecture were his friends since Ishikawa Prefectural College (later (old-education-system) Fourth Higher School, and NISHIDA, SUZUKI and FUJIOKA were called Kaga's santaro.
sen.cmt: 第四高等学校は Fourth Higher Schoolとしました。（講談社「対訳日本を作った100人」より）
sen.e: Daisetsu SUZUKI (real name: Sadataro), Ryokichi YAMAMOTO and Sakutaro FUJIOKA of the same prefecture had been his friends since Ishikawa Prefectural College (which late became Fourth High School), and Nishida, Suzuki and Fujioka were known as the 'Kaga no San Taro' (lit. the three Taro of Kaga).

Daisetsu SUZUKI (real name: Sadataro), Ryokichi YAMAMOTO and Sakutaro FUJIOKA of the same prefecture had been his friends since Ishikawa Prefectural College (which late became Fourth High School), and Nishida, Suzuki and Fujioka were known as the 'Kaga no San Taro' (lit. the three Taro of Kaga).

sen.j: 現在の石川県かほく市森（旧宇ノ気町森）に、西田得登（やすのり）、寅三（とさ）の長男として生まれる。
sen.e: He was born in Kahokushimori (former Mori, Unoke-machi) in Ishikawa Prefecture as the first son of Yasunori NISHIDA and Tosa.
He was born in Kahokushimori (former Mori, Unoke-machi) in Ishikawa Prefecture as the first son of Yasunori and Tosa NISHIDA.
He was born in Kahokushimori (former Mori, Unoke-machi) in Ishikawa Prefecture as the first son of Yasunori and Tosa NISHIDA.

sen.j: 西田家は江戸時代には十村制（大庄屋）を務めた豪家だった。
sen.e: The NISHIDA family was a wealthy farmer who served as Tomura-sei (a system of the big village headman) (Ojoya) (supervisor) in the Edo period.
The Nishida family were wealthy and served as district officials under the Tomura-sei (ten village system) in the Edo period.
The Nishida family were wealthy and served as district officials under the Tomura-sei (ten village system) in the Edo period.

sen.j: 若い時は、肉親の死、学歴での差別（東京大学における選科への待遇）、妻との一度の離縁など、多くの苦難を味わった。
sen.e: When young, he had many difficulties, such as death of parents, discrimination against academic background (treatment of elective courses in Tokyo University), and divorce.

When young, he underwent many difficulties such as the deaths of family members, discrimination against his academic background (treatment with regard to elective courses at Tokyo University) and divorce.

When young, he underwent many difficulties such as the deaths of family members, discrimination against his academic background (treatment with regard to elective courses at Tokyo University) and divorce.

sen.j: そのためか、大学を出た後は故郷に戻って中学の教師となり、同時に思索に耽った。
sen.e: After he graduated from the university, he went back to his hometown, became a teacher of a junior high school, and addicted his mind to speculation.
After graduating from university, he returned to his hometown where he became a junior high school teacher, and engaged his mind in thought.
After graduating from university, he returned to his hometown where he became a junior high school teacher, and engaged his mind in thought.

sen.j: その頃の考えが温まって、最も著名な著書、『善の研究』（弘道館、1911年1月）に繋がった。
sen.e: He put his thoughts together and wrote his most famous work, "Zen no kenkyu (A study of Good) (Kodokan, January, 1991)".
He put his thoughts together and wrote his most famous work entitled "Zen no Kenkyu (A study of Good) (Kodokan, January, 1991)".
He put his thoughts together and wrote his most famous work entitled "Zen no Kenkyu" (A study of Good) (Kodokan, January, 1991).

sen.j: 同書は、旧制高等学校の生徒にとって必読書であった。
sen.e: This book was a "must have" book for students of old-education-system high schools.
This book was a "must have" book for students of old-education-system high schools.
This book was a "must have" book for students of old-education-system high schools.

sen.j: 鎌倉にて、尿毒症により急逝。
sen.e: He died of uremia suddenly in Kamakura.
He died suddenly of uremia in Kamakura.
He died suddenly of uremia in Kamakura.

sen.j: 法名は曠然院明道寸心居士。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Kozenin Meido Sunshin Koji.
sen.cmt: 曠然院明道寸心居士はKozenin Meido Sunshin Kojiとしました。
sen.e: His posthumous Buddhist name is Kozenin Meido Sunshin Koji.
His posthumous Buddhist name is Kozenin Meido Sunshin Koji.

sen.j: 西田幾多郎が散策した琵琶湖疎水沿いの道は「哲学の道」と呼ばれ、日本の道百選にも選ばれている。
sen.e: The road along a canal of Lake Buwa, on which Kitaro took a walk, is called 'Philosopher's Walk"" and has been selected as one of 100 Japanese famous roads.
The road along a canal of Lake Buwa, on which Kitaro walked, is called 'Philosopher's Walk' and has been selected as one of the 100 famous Japanese roads.
The road along a canal of Lake Buwa, on which Kitaro walked, is called 'Philosopher's Walk' and has been selected as one of the 100 famous Japanese roads.

sen.j: 1884年 石川師範学校予備科卒業
sen.e: 1884 Graduated from Ishikawa Normal Preparatory School.
1884: Graduated from Ishikawa Normal Preparatory School.

sen.j: 1888年 第四高等学校 (旧制)予科修了
sen.e: 1988 Finished the preliminary course of (old-education-system) Fourth Higher School.
1988: Completed the Fourth High School (old-education-system) preparatory course.

sen.j: 1890年 第四高等中学校中途退学
sen.e: 1890 Dropped out of Fourth Higher School.
1890: Dropped out of Fourth High School.
1890: Dropped out of Fourth High School.

sen.j: 1894年 東京大学文科大学哲学科選科卒業
sen.e: 1894 Graduated from the elective course of the department of philosophy of Tokyo University.
1894: Graduated from an elective course at the Tokyo University Department of Philosophy.
1894: Graduated from an elective course at the Tokyo University Department of Philosophy.

sen.j: 1895年 石川県能登尋常中学校七尾分校教諭（4月）、得田寿美と結婚（5月）
sen.e: 1895 Became a teacher of a branch school of Ishikawa Prefecture Noto Jinjo Chuggako (old-education-system junior high school) (April), married to Kotomi TOKUDA (May).
1895: Became a teacher of a branch school of Ishikawa Prefecture Noto Jinjo Chuggako (old-education-system junior high school) (April), and married to Kotomi TOKUDA (May).

sen.j: 1896年 第四高等学校 (旧制)講師
sen.e: 1896 Lecturer of (old-education-system) Fourth Higher School
1896: Lecturer of Fourth Higher School (old-education-system).

sen.j: 1897年 この頃から参禅への関心が高まり、雪門、滴水、広州、虎関の諸禅師に就く
sen.e: 1897 Interested in practices of Zen meditation and studied under Zen masters of Setsumon, Tekisui, Koshu and Kokan.
1897: Increased interest Zen meditation and studied under Zen masters Setsumon, Tekisui, Koshu and Kokan.
1897: Increased interest Zen meditation and studied under Zen masters Setsumon, Tekisui, Koshu and Kokan.

sen.j: 1899年 山口高等学校 (旧制)（旧旧山高）教授（3月）、第四高等学校教授（7月。心理、論理、倫理、ドイツ語を担当）、臥龍山雪門老師に参禅
sen.e: 1899 Professor of (old-education-system) Yamaguchi High School (former Kyuyamako) (March), professor of Fourth Higher School (July. He taught psychology, logic, ethics and German.), practiced Zen meditation under a Zen master of Garyusan Setsumon.
sen.cmt: 旧山高はKyuyamakoとしました。旧制山口高等学校の略とインターネットにありました。臥龍山雪門老師Garyuzan Setsumon Roshi
sen.e: 1899: Professor of Yamaguchi High School (old-education-system) (formerly Kyuyamako) (March), professor of Fourth High School (In July, he taught psychology, logic, ethics and German), practiced Zen meditation under a Zen master Garyusan Setsumon.

sen.j: 1900年 同僚の三竹、杉森とともに三々塾を作り、学生指導に当たる
sen.e: 1900 Established a private school called Sansanjuku with colleagues Mitake and Sugimori and guided students.
1900: Established a private school called Sansanjuku with colleagues Mitake and Sugimori where he and guided students.
1900: Established a private school called Sansanjuku with colleagues Mitake and Sugimori where he and guided students.

sen.j: 1901年 雪門老師から寸心居士の号を受ける
sen.e: 1901 Received a title of Sunshin Koji from a Zen master of Garyusan Setsumon.
sen.cmt: 寸心居士はSunshin Kojiとしました。
sen.e: 1901: Received the title of Sunshin Koji from a Zen master Garyusan Setsumon.
1901: Received the title of Sunshin Koji from a Zen master Setsumon.

sen.j: 1903年 京都大徳寺孤蓬庵広州老師に参じ、無字の公案透過
sen.e: 1903 Practiced Zen meditation under a Zen master of kohoan Kosyu of Daitoku-ji Temple in Kyoto, answered to kouan (Zen question for meditation) and received authorization.
sen.cmt: 無字の公案透過は、「公案を透過して無字の認可を与えられた」という意味と解しました。
sen.e: 1903: Practiced Zen meditation under Zen master Kohoan Kosyu of Daitoku-ji Temple in Kyoto, responded to kouan (a method to learn the secrets of Zen by providing questions to a person seeking the secrets) and received authorization.

1903: Practiced Zen meditation under Zen master Kohoan Koshu of Daitoku-ji Temple in Kyoto, responded to koan (a method to learn the secrets of Zen by providing questions to a person seeking the secrets) and received authorization.

sen.j: 1905年 富山県国泰寺で瑞雲老師に参じる
sen.e: 1905 Practiced Zen meditation under a Zen master of Zuiun in Kokutai-ji Temple in Toyama Prefecture.
1905: Practiced Zen meditation under Zen master Zuiun at Kokutai-ji Temple in Toyama Prefecture.
1905: Practiced Zen meditation under Zen master Zuiun at Kokutai-ji Temple in Toyama Prefecture.

sen.j: 1909年 学習院教授（7月）、日本大学講師（10月）
sen.e: 1909 Became a professor of Gakushuin University (July), a lecturer of Nihon University (October).
1909: Became a professor at Gakushuin University (July), and a lecturer at Nihon University (October).
1909: Became a professor at Gakushuin University (July), and a lecturer at Nihon University (October).

sen.j: 1910年 豊山大学（現・大正大学）講師（4月）、京都帝国大学文科大学助教授（8月。倫理学）
sen.e: 1910 Became a lecturer of Buzan University (present Taisho University) (April), and assistant professor of the literature department of Kyoto Imperial University (August, Ethics).
1910: Became a lecturer at Buzan University (present Taisho University) (April), and assistant professor of the literature department of Kyoto Imperial University (August, Ethics).
1910: Became a lecturer at Buzan University (present Taisho University) (April), and assistant professor of the literature department of Kyoto Imperial University (August, Ethics).

sen.j: 1911年 真宗大谷大学（現・大谷大学）講師
sen.e: 1911 Became a lecturer of Shinshu Otani University (present Otani University).
sen.cmt: 真宗大谷大学は、Shinshu Otani Universityと仮訳しました。
sen.e: 1911: Became a lecturer at Shinshu Otani University (present Otani University).
1911: Became a lecturer at Shinshu Otani University (present Otani University).

sen.j: 1912年 京都高等工芸学校（現・京都工芸繊維大学）講師
sen.e: 1912 Became a lecturer of Kyoto Higher School of Design (current Kyoto Institute of Technology).
sen.cmt: 京都高等工芸学校は、Kyoto Higher School of Designとしました。
sen.e: 1912: Became a lecturer at Kyoto Higher School of Design (current Kyoto Institute of Technology).
1912: Became a lecturer at Kyoto Higher School of Design (current Kyoto Institute of Technology).

sen.j: 1913年 京都帝国大学文科大学教授（8月。宗教学）、文学博士（12月）
sen.e: 1913 Became a professor (science of religion) of the literature department of Kyoto Imperial University (August) and a doctor of literature (December).
1913: Became a professor (religious studies) at the literature department of Kyoto Imperial University (August) and a doctor of literature (December).
sen.cmt: Added commascience of religion > religious studiesof > at
sen.e: 1913: Became a professor (religious studies) at the literature department of Kyoto Imperial University (August) and a doctor of literature (December).

sen.j: 1914年 宗教学講座担当を免じ、哲学、哲学史第一講座担任を命じられる
sen.e: 1914 Discharged from science of religion and took charge in the first course o philosophy and history of philosophy.
1914: Dismissed from the religious studies course and appointed to the first course of philosophy and history of philosophy.
1914: Dismissed from the religious studies course and appointed to the first course of philosophy and history of philosophy.

sen.j: 1927年 帝国学士院会員
sen.e: 1927 Became a member of the Imperial Academy.
192:7 Became a member of the Imperial Academy.
1927: Became a member of the Imperial Academy.

sen.j: 1928年 京都帝国大学停年退職
sen.e: 1928 Retired from Kyoto Imperial University
1928: Retired from Kyoto Imperial University
1928: Retired from Kyoto Imperial University

sen.j: 1929年 京都帝国大学名誉教授
sen.e: 1929 Became an honorary professor of Kyoto Imperial University.
1929: Became an honorary professor of Kyoto Imperial University.
1929: Became an honorary professor of Kyoto Imperial University.

sen.j: 1931年 山田琴と再婚（12月）
sen.e: 1931 Remarried to Koto YAMADA (December).
1931: Remarried to Koto YAMADA (December).

sen.j: 1940年 文化勲章受章
sen.e: 1940 Received the Order of Culture.
1940: Received the Order of Culture.
1940: Received the Order of Culture.

sen.j: 彼の哲学体系は西田哲学と呼ばれたが、このように体系にその名が付けられるのは日本の近代以降の哲学者の中では唯一と言って過言ではない。
sen.e: The system of his philosophy is called Nishida philosophy, and it is not exaggeration to say that he was the only philosopher whose name was given to his philosophy in recent times of Japan.

His philosophical system is called Nishida Philosophy, and it is not an exaggeration to say that he was the only philosopher in recent Japanese history to have had a philosophical system named after him.

His philosophical system is called Nishida Philosophy, and it is not an exaggeration to say that he was the only philosopher in recent Japanese history to have had a philosophical system named after him.

sen.j: 郷里に近い国泰寺 (高岡市)での禅経験（居士号は寸心）と近代哲学を基礎に、仏教思想、西洋哲学をより根本的な地点から融合させようとした。
sen.e: He tried to merge Buddhist concepts with Western philosophy from a more fundamental aspect based on his experience of Zen meditation (Sunshin Koji) in Kokutai-ji Temple (Takaoka City) near his hometown.

He tried to merge Buddhist concepts with Western philosophy from a more fundamental aspect based on his experience of Zen meditation (Sunshin Koji) in Kokutai-ji Temple (Takaoka City) near his hometown.

He tried to merge Buddhist concepts with Western philosophy from a more fundamental aspect based on his experience of Zen meditation (Sunshin Koji) in Kokutai-ji Temple (Takaoka City) and philosophy in recent times near his hometown.

sen.j: その思索は禅仏教の「無の境地」を哲学論理化した純粋経験論から、その純粋経験を自覚する事によって自己発展していく自覚論、そして、その自覚など、意識の存在する場としての場の論理論、最終的にその場が宗教的・道徳的に統合される絶対矛盾的自己同一論へと展開していった。
sen.e: His thoughts developed from the pure experience theory (which theorized the 'state of nothing' into the self-consciousness theory (one develops himself by recognizing his pure experience), logicalness theory as a field in which consciousness, such as awareness, exists and absolutely paradoxical identity theory (the field is finally integrated religiously and ethically.

His thoughts developed from the pure experience theory (which theorized the 'state of nothing') into the self-consciousness theory (one develops himself by recognizing his pure experience), logicalness theory as a field in which consciousness, such as awareness, exists and absolutely paradoxical identity theory (the field is finally integrated religiously and ethically.

His thoughts developed from the pure experience theory (which theorized the 'state of nothing') of Zen Buddhism into the self-consciousness theory (one develops himself by recognizing his pure experience), logicalness theory as a field in which consciousness, such as awareness, exists and absolutely paradoxical identity theory (the field is finally integrated religiously and ethically).
sen.cmt: 訳漏れ補足しました。)補足しました。

sen.j: 一方で、一見するだけでは年代的に思想が展開されているように見えながら、西田は最初期から最晩年まで同じ地点を様々な角度で眺めていた、と解釈する見方もあり、現在では研究者（特に禅関係）の間でかなり広く受け入れられている。
sen.e: Some think that while his ideas seemed to be developed chronologically at a glance, NISHIDA viewed the same point from the first to the last stage from various angles, and now this opinion has been widely accepted among researchers (especially those associated with Zen).

Although at a glance, his ideas appear have developed chronologically, there is also the interpretation that NISHIDA viewed the same point from a variety of angles from the outset to his final years, and this viewpoint is now widely accepted among research (particularly those associated with Zen).

Although at a glance, his ideas appear to have developed chronologically, there is also the interpretation that NISHIDA viewed the same point from a variety of angles from the outset to his final years, and this viewpoint is now widely accepted among researchers (particularly those associated with Zen).

sen.j: 最晩年に示された「絶対矛盾的自己同一」は、哲学用語と言うより宗教用語のように崇められたり、逆に厳しく批判されたりした。
sen.e: The 'absolutely paradoxical identity theory' shown in his last years was evaluated or criticized severely as a religious term rather than a philosophical term.
The 'absolutely paradoxical identity theory' shown in his last years was harshly criticized as being a religious term as opposed to a philosophical term.
The 'absolutely paradoxical identity theory' shown in his last years was evaluated or harshly criticized as being a religious term as opposed to a philosophical term.
sen.cmt: was harshly criticized→was evaluated or harshly criticized

sen.j: その要旨は「過去と未来とが現在において互いに否定しあいながらも結びついて、現在から現在へと働いていく」、あるいは、鈴木大拙の「即非の論理」（「Aは非Aであり、それによってまさにAである」という金剛経に通底する思想）を西洋哲学の中で捉え直した「場所的論理」（「自己は自己を否定するところにおいて真の自己である」）とも言われている。
sen.e: It is said that it can be summarized as 'the past and the future deny each other, but join together at the present and move from the present to the present' or 'the Logic of Topos (locational logic)' (the self is a true self when the self denies itself') which reinterprets 'the Logic of Sokuhi (Superrational Logic)' (an idea in Kongo-kyo Sutra that 'A is non-A and therefore is A') of Daisetsu SUZUKI in Western philosophy.

It is said that it can be summarized as 'the past and the future deny each other, but join together at the present and move from the present to the present' or 'the Logic of Topos (locational logic)' (the self is a true self when the self denies itself') which reinterprets 'the Logic of Sokuhi (Superrational Logic)' (an idea in Kongo-kyo Sutra that 'A is non-A and therefore is A') of Daisetsu SUZUKI in Western philosophy.

It is said that it can be summarized as 'the past and the future deny each other, but join together at the present and move from the present to the present' or 'the Logic of Topos' (locational logic) (the self is a true self when the self denies itself') which reinterprets 'the Logic of Sokuhi' (Superrational Logic) (an idea in Kongo-kyo Sutra that 'A is non-A and therefore is A') of Daisetsu SUZUKI in Western philosophy.

sen.j: そこには、行動と思想とが言語道断で不可分だった西田哲学の真髄が現れている。
sen.e: It is the essence of the NISHIDA philosophy in which behavior and ideas are unutterable and inseparable.
It is the essence of the NISHIDA philosophy in which behavior and ideas are unutterable and inseparable.
It is the essence of the Nishida philosophy in which behavior and ideas are unutterable and inseparable.

sen.j: 論文『場所的論理と宗教的世界観』で西田は「宗教は心霊上の事実である。
sen.e: In his thesis "the Logic of Topos (locational logic) and Religious Worldview", NISHIDA said that 'Religion was a psychic fact.
In his thesis "the Logic of Topos (locational logic) and Religious Worldview", NISHIDA said that 'Religion was a psychic fact.
In his thesis "the Logic of Topos (locational logic) and Religious Worldview," Nishida said that 'Religion was a psychic fact.
sen.cmt: カンマ位置移動人名修正

sen.j: 哲学者が自己の体系の上から宗教を捏造すべきではない。
sen.e: Philosophers should not forge religion based on their system of philosophy.
Philosophers should not forge religion based on their system of philosophy.
Philosophers should not forge religion based on their system of philosophy.

sen.j: 哲学者はこの心霊上の事実を説明せなければならない。」と記している。
sen.e: They must explain this psychic fact'.
They must explain this psychic fact'.
They must explain this psychic fact.'

sen.j: 西田は思想輸入的・文献学的なアプローチを取らず、先人らの思考法だけを学び独自に思想を展開させたがゆえに、彼の著作は一見すると独創的で難解である。
sen.e: NISHIDA did not use an approach that imported ideas or a philological approach, learned only ways of thinking of his predecessors, developed his ideas uniquely, and therefore, his works are original and difficult to understand at first sight.

NISHIDA did not use an approach that imported ideas or a philological approach, learned only ways of thinking of his predecessors, developed his ideas uniquely, and therefore, his works are original and difficult to understand at first sight.

Nishida did not use an approach that imported ideas or a philological approach, learned only ways of thinking of his predecessors, developed his ideas uniquely, and therefore, his works are original and difficult to understand at first sight.

sen.j: しかし、禅の実践から抽出された独自の学風は文献学者、「哲学学者」への痛烈なアンチテーゼでもありえよう。
sen.e: But his original method of study that was created from practices of Zen meditation can be a devastating antithesis to philologists and 'philosophy scholars'.
But his original method of study that was created from practices of Zen meditation can be a devastating antithesis to philologists and 'philosophy scholars'.
But his original method of study that was created from practices of Zen meditation can be a devastating antithesis to philologists and 'philosophy scholars.'

sen.j: 一方、田辺元や高橋里美などから西田哲学はあまりにも宗教的であり、実践的でないという批判された。
sen.e: On the other hand, Hajime TANABE and Satomi TAKAHASHI criticized that NISHIDA philosophy was too religious to be practical.
On the other hand, Hajime TANABE and Satomi TAKAHASHI criticized the NISHIDA philosophy as being too religious to be practical.
On the other hand, Hajime TANABE and Satomi TAKAHASHI criticized the Nishida philosophy as being too religious to be practical.

sen.j: 西田外彦 甲南大学（旧制）教授 次男
sen.e: Sotohiko NISHIDA Professor of Konan University (old-education-system), second son
His second son is Sotohiko NISHIDA - a professor at Konan University (old-education-system).
His second son is Sotohiko NISHIDA - a professor at Konan University (old-education-system).

sen.j: 西田幾久彦 財団法人日本ゴルフ協会理事、元東京銀行常務、外彦の長男、正仁親王妃華子の義兄
sen.e: Kikuhiko NISHIDA Director of the Professional Golfers' Association of Japan, former executive of Bank of Tokyo Ltd., first son of Sotohiko, brother-in-law of Princess Hanako, the wife of Imperial Prince Masahito

His first son is Kikuhiko NISHIDA - Director of the Professional Golfers' Association of Japan, former executive of the Bank of Tokyo Ltd., the elder brother of Sotohiko, and the brother-in-law of Princess Hanako who the wife of Princess Hitachi.
